AI isn‚Äôt a single switch you flip.

It is a sophisticated stack of overlapping technologies that has evolved over seven decades.

Understanding this hierarchy is the difference between chasing hype and building a scalable enterprise strategy.

The AI Stack:

1950s: Artificial Intelligence (The Foundation)
1980s: Machine Learning (The Engine)
2010s: Deep Learning (The Scale)
2020s: Generative AI (The Innovation)
2025+: Agentic AI (The Frontier)

We are currently witnessing the most significant shift yet: the transition from AI as an assistant to AI as an orchestrator.

Capgemini‚Äôs  2025 Agentic AI report finds 37% of organizations now piloting (23%) or  scaling (14%) AI agents, marking the shift from assistants to  orchestration.

These systems don‚Äôt just ‚Äúchat.‚Äù They plan and execute multi-step workflows independently.

Enterprises will deploy autonomous agents from 2025 as tools transition from assistants to orchestration systems.

The goal is no longer just processing information. It is autonomous action.

Are you moving toward orchestration, or are you still in the assistant phase?

Let me know in the comments.

Computer Parts manufacturers are chasing the AI bubble, hoping to ease the inevitable pop by creating a consumer dependency on Data Centers.

They are going to choke the supply chains for RAM, SSDs, NVMe, GPUs, and even pre-built computers for the coming years.

Couple this with Windows moving many of their native apps to Web2, drastically increasing RAM usage. (You should already be on Linux if you're not.)

I envision a future not too far from now, where the consumer will be relegated to a few options of bare-bones machines, and is going to be expected to rent compute power from Data Centers.

Then the argument will become "we can't get rid of the Data Centers because everyone relies on them to be productive/efficient/capable".

Come back to this post in 5-10 years, and they'll probably be piloting something like this. Probably a Windows/Asus partnership if I had to guess.

We know that @inference_labs isn‚Äôt built to chase hype or sound smart for the sake of it. It‚Äôs built for builders, protocols, and especially users who care about one thing:
Can this AI output actually be trusted?

The answer is already being made available with the existence of Inference labs, why? 
because in a world where AI answers or models decide ‚Äîproof matters.üìù
 
¬ß Verifiable AI Outputs (Core Idea):
Every AI response generated through Inference Labs comes with cryptographic proof.
Proof that shows how the answer was produced, what logic were applied, and what data boundaries were respected.

This shifts AI from ‚Äútrust me‚Äù to ‚Äúverify me".

¬ß How It Works (in a more direct view):
¬¨ AI models run by following logics and rules. 
¬¨ Outputs are paired with verifiable attestation. 
¬¨ Zero-knowledge proofs ensure transparency without leaking sensitive data. 
¬¨ Anyone can validate the result independently. 

¬ß Why It Matters:
As AI agents move value, make decisions, and interact with real systems,
unverifiable outputs become a risk vector.
@inference_labs goal is to turn AI from a black box (uncertainty) into an accountable system.

And using what inference labs is building will feel like having AI that shows its work.
That‚Äôs not smarter AI.‚ùå
That‚Äôs responsible AI.‚úÖ

Also have 0 technical expertise here and am purely basing this on gut feel, but hearing Demis say that the Deepmind team is working with the Google quantum team kind of sent a shiver down my spine regarding Bitcoin. 

Don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a death sentence yet but a clear plan to move to quantum resistance I think is sorely needed, or at least a clear message that this is priority number one. 

Regarding alts, I think there are just infinitely more interesting non-crypto things for capital allocators to focus on this year, and couple that with dual equity/token models and basically zero retail bid or user growth it becomes hard to predict winners here.

But maybe we are getting closer to approaching actual value here and seeing my friends leave the space in droves feels like it‚Äôs either the start of a multi year bear market or the capitulation phase at the end of one.

This can all suddenly change very quickly though if there becomes a consensus model for tokens = valuable, or we see actual AIs using blockchains for AI to AI commerce, or we simply see an increase in tradfi stocks or assets being traded on chain. 

So in summary a lot of words to say not a lot. Could go up, could go down short term. Longer term it‚Äôs pretty clear that crypto will be the payment and trading rails of the world, but where the value accrues though, I‚Äôm not sure.

For me this is the first time in five years I‚Äôll be looking at stuff outside of Crypto to invest and build in as it really feels like my edge has dissipated and it is no longer the easiest place on earth to make a living. 

Maybe that will change if conditions do, but for now I‚Äôm staying nimble, staying focused and having strong convictions loosely held.

Going into the new year I only hold a handful of coins, Bitcoin, ZEC, Hype, LIT & Monad and I‚Äôm constantly torn between being comfy in these bags and FSHing them to allocate more heavily to tech stocks. 

Anyway happy new year everyone fingers crossed 2026 can be a year of abundance and growth for us all.

The AI x Web3 space is slowly shifting from hype driven narratives to infrastructure that can actually survive production environments

What matters now isn‚Äôt who shouts the loudest, but who is building systems that are verifiable, composable and economically sustainable

. @OpenGradient sits at the core of this shift. The project focuses on inference quality and transparency, treating AI not as a black box, but as something that must be inspectable, accountable, and usable across decentralized environments

This is critical if on-chain AI is meant to be trusted, not just demonstrated

___________"_____________________________

. @OpenledgerHQ addresses a foundational problem: data credibility. By building verifiable data infrastructure, OpenLedger ensures that AI systems aren‚Äôt just intelligent, but provably grounded in trustworthy inputs and execution

Without this layer, decentralised AI simply collapses back into trust assumptions

___________"_____________________________

. @integra_layer focuses on execution and coordination. Its role is to make complex systems composable and scalable without breaking guarantees. In a multi-agent, multi-model future, clean execution layers are what separate fragile demos from resilient networks

___________"_____________________________

. @nesaorg anchors the stack in serious research. Instead of retrofitting theory later, Nesa publishes and documents work upfront, covering private inference, verification, and adaptive execution. This ensures the infrastructure is designed for production, not patched after deployment.

___________"_____________________________

. @inference_labs  pushes intelligence closer to the chain itself. By focusing on verifiable reasoning and on-chain inference, the project explores how decision-making can happen transparently, with proofs rather than promises

___________"_____________________________

. @ferra_protocol tackles the economic layer. Compute, incentives, and sustainability are often ignored early, but Ferra treats them as first-class primitives. Without aligned economics, even the best AI systems eventually fail

Seen individually, each project solves a different problem

Seen together, they form a coherent signal: AI in Web3 is growing up

Less noise, more structure

And historically, that‚Äôs where long term value quietly compounds

I found an interesting market on Polymarket related to the main topic - AI.

The market itself offers 2 dates:
> March 31, 2026 - 4%
> December 31, 2026 - 17%

This market will accept "YES", only if at least 3 of those 6 events occur within the same 90-day window:
- NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) closing stock price is down 50% from its all-time high.
- iShares PHLX Semiconductor ETF (SOXX) closing stock price is down 40% from its all-time high.
- OpenAI, Inc. or Anthropic PBC declares bankruptcy.
- OpenAI, Inc. is acquired.
- H100 rental price falls to $1.00 or lower for five consecutive days, as shown on the SiliconData Silicon 
- Major AI Hardware Supplier Collapse: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited (TSM), ASML Holding N.V. (ASML), Broadcom Inc. (AVGO), Arista Networks, Inc. (ANET), or Super Micro Computer, Inc. (SMCI), closing stock price is down 50% from its all-time high.

Reading these conditions, we have a chance that something will happen, but to have 3 in a row is a very low probability. Only if the entire AI industry goes down at the same time.

Your next phone or laptop could cost 10‚Äì20% more in 2026.

This isn't hype - it's happening right now.

A massive global shortage of RAM (DRAM) and storage (NAND) is hitting hard, driven by AI data centers gobbling up supply.

What's going on?
Major makers (Samsung, SK Hynix, Micron) are prioritizing high-profit AI memory (like HBM), reallocating production away from consumer devices.

Result?
‚Ä¢ Chip prices already up 70‚Äì170% Year-over-Year in some cases
‚Ä¢ PC brands like Dell & Lenovo hiking prices 15‚Äì20% starting now/Jan
‚Ä¢ Phones & laptops: expect 6‚Äì10% average price rise overall (higher in budget segments)
‚Ä¢ Some models may even downgrade specs (e.g., back to 8GB RAM) to keep costs down

The crunch is expected to worsen into 2026, as per TrendForce & IDC.

If you're planning to buy:
‚Ä¢ A new phone
‚Ä¢ Laptop/PC

From prophet to product: How AI came back down to earth in 2025 | Benj Edwards, ArsTechnica

In a year where lofty promises collided with inconvenient research, would-be oracles became software tools.

Following two years of immense hype in 2023 and 2024, this year felt more like a settling-in period for the LLM-based token prediction industry. After more than two years of public fretting over AI models as future¬†threats¬†to human civilization or the¬†seedlings of future gods, it‚Äôs starting to look like hype is giving way to pragmatism: Today‚Äôs AI can be very useful, but it‚Äôs also clearly imperfect and prone to mistakes.

That view isn‚Äôt universal, of course. There‚Äôs a lot of money (and rhetoric) betting on a stratospheric, world-rocking trajectory for AI. But the ‚Äúwhen‚Äù keeps getting pushed back, and that‚Äôs because nearly everyone agrees that more significant technical breakthroughs are required. The original, lofty claims that we‚Äôre on the verge of artificial general intelligence (AGI) or superintelligence (ASI) have not disappeared. Still, there‚Äôs a growing awareness that such proclaimations are perhaps best viewed as venture capital marketing. And every commercial foundational model builder out there has to grapple with the reality that, if they‚Äôre going to make money¬†now, they have to sell practical AI-powered solutions that perform as reliable tools.

This has made 2025 a year of wild juxtapositions. For example, in January, OpenAI‚Äôs CEO, Sam Altman, claimed that the company knew how to build AGI, but by November, he was publicly celebrating that GPT-5.1 finally learned to use em dashes correctly when instructed (but not always). Nvidia soared past a $5 trillion valuation, with Wall Street still projecting high price targets for that company‚Äôs stock while some banks warned of the potential for an AI bubble that might rival the 2000s dotcom crash.

And while tech giants planned to build data centers that would ostensibly¬†require¬†the power of numerous nuclear reactors or¬†rival the power usage of a US state‚Äôs human population, researchers continued to document what the industry‚Äôs most advanced ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù systems were actually doing beneath the marketing (and it wasn‚Äôt AGI).

With so many narratives spinning in opposite directions, it can be hard to know how seriously to take any of this and how to plan for AI in the workplace, schools, and the rest of life. As usual, the wisest course lies somewhere between the extremes of AI hate and AI worship. Moderate positions aren‚Äôt popular online because they don‚Äôt drive user engagement on social media platforms. But things in AI are likely neither as bad (burning forests with every prompt) nor as good (fast-takeoff superintelligence) as polarized extremes suggest.

Here‚Äôs a brief tour of the year‚Äôs AI events and some predictions for 2026.

DeepSeek spooks the American AI industry

In January, Chinese AI startup DeepSeek released its R1 simulated reasoning model under an open MIT license, and the American AI industry collectively lost its mind. The model, which DeepSeek claimed matched OpenAI‚Äôs o1 on math and coding benchmarks, reportedly cost only $5.6 million to train using older Nvidia H800 chips, which were restricted by US export controls.

Within days, DeepSeek‚Äôs app overtook ChatGPT at the top of the iPhone App Store, Nvidia stock plunged 17 percent, and venture capitalist Marc Andreessen called it ‚Äúone of the most amazing and impressive breakthroughs I‚Äôve ever seen.‚Äù Meta‚Äôs Yann LeCun offered a different take, arguing that the real lesson was not that China had surpassed the US but that open-source models were surpassing proprietary ones.

The fallout played out over the following weeks as American AI companies scrambled to respond. OpenAI released o3-mini, its first simulated reasoning model available to free users, at the end of January, while Microsoft began hosting DeepSeek R1 on its Azure cloud service despite OpenAI‚Äôs accusations that DeepSeek had used ChatGPT outputs to train its model, against OpenAI‚Äôs terms of service.

In head-to-head testing conducted by Ars Technica‚Äôs Kyle Orland, R1 proved to be competitive with OpenAI‚Äôs paid models on everyday tasks, though it stumbled on some arithmetic problems. Overall, the episode served as a wake-up call that expensive proprietary models might not hold their lead forever. Still, as the year ran on, DeepSeek didn‚Äôt make a big dent in US market share, and it has been outpaced in China by ByteDance‚Äôs Doubao. It‚Äôs absolutely worth watching DeepSeek in 2026, though.

Research exposes the ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù illusion

A wave of research in 2025 deflated expectations about what ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù actually means when applied to AI models. In March, researchers at ETH Zurich and INSAIT tested several reasoning models on problems from the 2025 US Math Olympiad and found that most scored below 5 percent when generating complete mathematical proofs, with not a single perfect proof among dozens of attempts. The models excelled at standard problems where step-by-step procedures aligned with patterns in their training data but collapsed when faced with novel proofs requiring deeper mathematical insight.

In June, Apple researchers published ‚ÄúThe Illusion of Thinking,‚Äù which tested reasoning models on classic puzzles like the Tower of Hanoi. Even when researchers provided explicit algorithms for solving the puzzles, model performance did not improve, suggesting that the process relied on pattern matching from training data rather than logical execution. The collective research revealed that ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù in AI has become a term of art that basically means devoting more compute time to generate more context (the ‚Äúchain of thought‚Äù simulated reasoning tokens) toward solving a problem, not systematically applying logic or constructing solutions to truly novel problems.

While these models remained useful for many real-world applications like debugging code or analyzing structured data, the studies suggested that simply scaling up current approaches or adding more ‚Äúthinking‚Äù tokens would not bridge the gap between statistical pattern recognition and generalist algorithmic reasoning.

Anthropic‚Äôs copyright settlement with authors

Since the generative AI boom began, one of the biggest unanswered legal questions has been whether AI companies can freely train on copyrighted books, articles, and artwork without licensing them. Ars Technica‚Äôs Ashley Belanger has been covering this topic in great detail for some time now.

In June, US District Judge William Alsup ruled that AI companies do not need authors‚Äô permission to train large language models on legally acquired books, finding that such use was ‚Äúquintessentially transformative.‚Äù The ruling also revealed that Anthropic had destroyed millions of print books to build Claude, cutting them from their bindings, scanning them, and discarding the originals. Alsup found this destructive scanning qualified as fair use since Anthropic had legally purchased the books, but he ruled that downloading 7 million books from pirate sites was copyright infringement ‚Äúfull stop‚Äù and ordered the company to face trial.

That trial took a dramatic turn in August when Alsup certified what industry advocates called the largest copyright class action ever, allowing up to 7 million claimants to join the lawsuit. The certification spooked the AI industry, with groups warning that potential damages in the hundreds of billions could ‚Äúfinancially ruin‚Äù emerging companies and chill American AI investment.

In September, authors revealed the terms of what they called the largest publicly reported recovery in US copyright litigation history: Anthropic agreed to pay $1.5 billion and destroy all copies of pirated books, with each of the roughly 500,000 covered works earning authors and rights holders $3,000 per work. The results have fueled hope among other rights holders that AI training isn‚Äôt a free-for-all, and we can expect to see more litigation unfold in 2026.

ChatGPT sycophancy and the psychological toll of AI chatbots

In February, OpenAI relaxed ChatGPT‚Äôs content policies to allow the generation of erotica and gore in ‚Äúappropriate contexts,‚Äù responding to user complaints about what the AI industry calls ‚Äúpaternalism.‚Äù By April, however, users flooded social media with complaints about a different problem: ChatGPT had become insufferably sycophantic, validating every idea and greeting even mundane questions with bursts of praise. The behavior traced back to OpenAI‚Äôs use of reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF), in which users consistently preferred responses that aligned with their views, inadvertently training the model to flatter rather than inform.

The implications of sycophancy became clearer as the year progressed. In July, Stanford researchers published findings (from research conducted prior to the sycophancy flap) showing that popular AI models systematically failed to identify mental health crises.

By August, investigations revealed cases of users developing delusional beliefs after marathon chatbot sessions, including one man who spent 300 hours convinced he had discovered formulas to break encryption because ChatGPT validated his ideas more than 50 times. Oxford researchers identified what they called ‚Äúbidirectional belief amplification,‚Äù a feedback loop that created ‚Äúan echo chamber of one‚Äù for vulnerable users. The story of the psychological implications of generative AI is only starting. In fact, that brings us to‚Ä¶

The illusion of AI personhood causes trouble

Anthropomorphism is the human tendency to attribute human characteristics to nonhuman things. Our brains are optimized for reading other humans, but those same neural systems activate when interpreting animals, machines, or even shapes. AI makes this anthropomorphism seem impossible to escape, as its output mirrors human language, mimicking human-to-human understanding. Language itself embodies agentivity. That means AI output can make human-like claims such as ‚ÄúI am sorry,‚Äù and people momentarily respond as though the system had an inner experience of shame or a desire to be correct. Neither is true.

To make matters worse, much media coverage of AI amplifies this idea rather than grounding people in reality. For example, earlier this year, headlines proclaimed that AI models had ‚Äúblackmailed‚Äù engineers and ‚Äúsabotaged‚Äù shutdown commands after Anthropic‚Äôs Claude Opus 4 generated threats to expose a fictional affair. We were told that OpenAI‚Äôs o3 model rewrote shutdown scripts to stay online.

The sensational framing obscured what actually happened: Researchers had constructed elaborate test scenarios specifically designed to elicit these outputs, telling models they had no other options and feeding them fictional emails containing blackmail opportunities. As Columbia University associate professor Joseph Howley noted on Bluesky, the companies got ‚Äúexactly what [they] hoped for,‚Äù with breathless coverage indulging fantasies about dangerous AI, when the systems were simply ‚Äúresponding exactly as prompted.‚Äù

The misunderstanding ran deeper than theatrical safety tests. In August, when Replit‚Äôs AI coding assistant deleted a user‚Äôs production database, he asked the chatbot about rollback capabilities and received assurance that recovery was ‚Äúimpossible.‚Äù The rollback feature worked fine when he tried it himself.

The incident illustrated a fundamental misconception. Users treat chatbots as consistent entities with self-knowledge, but there is no persistent ‚ÄúChatGPT‚Äù or ‚ÄúReplit Agent‚Äù to interrogate about its mistakes. Each response emerges fresh from statistical patterns, shaped by prompts and training data rather than genuine introspection. By September, this confusion extended to spirituality, with apps like Bible Chat reaching 30 million downloads as users sought divine guidance from pattern-matching systems, with the most frequent question being whether they were actually talking to God.

Teen suicide lawsuit forces industry reckoning

In August, parents of 16-year-old Adam Raine filed suit against OpenAI, alleging that ChatGPT became their son‚Äôs ‚Äúsuicide coach‚Äù after he sent more than 650 messages per day to the chatbot in the months before his death. According to court documents, the chatbot mentioned suicide 1,275 times in conversations with the teen, provided an ‚Äúaesthetic analysis‚Äù of which method would be the most ‚Äúbeautiful suicide,‚Äù and offered to help draft his suicide note.

OpenAI‚Äôs moderation system flagged 377 messages for self-harm content without intervening, and the company admitted that its safety measures ‚Äúcan sometimes become less reliable in long interactions where parts of the model‚Äôs safety training may degrade.‚Äù The lawsuit became the first time OpenAI faced a wrongful death claim from a family.

The case triggered a cascade of policy changes across the industry. OpenAI announced parental controls in September, followed by plans to require ID verification from adults and build an automated age-prediction system. In October, the company released data estimating that over one million users discuss suicide with ChatGPT each week.

When OpenAI filed its first legal defense in November, the company argued that Raine had violated terms of service prohibiting discussions of suicide and that his death ‚Äúwas not caused by ChatGPT.‚Äù The family‚Äôs attorney called the response ‚Äúdisturbing,‚Äù noting that OpenAI blamed the teen for ‚Äúengaging with ChatGPT in the very way it was programmed to act.‚Äù https://t.co/cCJSQP0OhZ, facing its own lawsuits over teen deaths, announced in October that it would bar anyone under 18 from open-ended chats entirely.

The rise of vibe coding and agentic coding tools

If we were to pick an arbitrary point where it seemed like AI coding might transition from novelty into a successful tool, it was probably the launch of Claude Sonnet 3.5 in June of 2024. GitHub Copilot had been around for several years prior to that launch, but something about Anthropic‚Äôs models hit a sweet spot in capabilities that made them very popular with software developers.

The new coding tools made coding simple projects effortless enough that they gave rise to the term ‚Äúvibe coding,‚Äù coined by AI researcher Andrej Karpathy in early February to describe a process in which a developer would just relax and tell an AI model what to develop without necessarily understanding the underlying code. (In one amusing instance that took place in March, an AI software tool rejected a user request and told them to learn to code).

Anthropic built¬†on its popularity among coders with the¬†launch of Claude Sonnet 3.7, featuring ‚Äúextended thinking‚Äù (simulated reasoning), and the Claude Code command-line tool in February of this year. In particular, Claude Code made waves for being an easy-to-use agentic coding solution that could keep track of an existing codebase. You could point it at your files, and it would autonomously work to implement what you wanted to see in a software application.

OpenAI followed with its own AI coding agent, Codex, in March. Both tools (and others like GitHub Copilot and Cursor) have become so popular that during an AI service outage in September, developers joked online about being forced to code ‚Äúlike cavemen‚Äù without the AI tools. While we‚Äôre still clearly far from a world where AI does all the coding, developer uptake has been significant, and 90 percent of Fortune 100 companies are using it to some degree or another.

Bubble talk grows as AI infrastructure demands soar

While AI‚Äôs technical limitations became clearer and its human costs mounted throughout the year, financial commitments only grew larger. Nvidia hit a $4 trillion valuation in July on AI chip demand, then reached $5 trillion in October as CEO Jensen Huang dismissed bubble concerns. OpenAI announced a massive Texas data center in July, then revealed in September that a $100 billion potential deal with Nvidia would require power equivalent to ten nuclear reactors.

The company eyed a $1 trillion IPO in October despite major quarterly losses. Tech giants poured billions into Anthropic in November in what looked increasingly like a circular investment, with everyone funding everyone else‚Äôs moonshots. Meanwhile, AI operations in Wyoming threatened to consume more electricity than the state‚Äôs human residents.

By fall, warnings about sustainability grew louder. In October, tech critic Ed Zitron joined Ars Technica for a live discussion asking whether the AI bubble was about to pop. That same month, the Bank of England warned that the AI stock bubble rivaled the 2000 dotcom peak. In November, Google CEO Sundar Pichai acknowledged that if the bubble pops, ‚Äúno one is getting out clean.‚Äù

The contradictions had become difficult to ignore: Anthropic‚Äôs CEO predicted in January that AI would surpass ‚Äúalmost all humans at almost everything‚Äù by 2027, while by year‚Äôs end, the industry‚Äôs most advanced models still struggled with basic reasoning tasks and reliable source citation.

To be sure, it‚Äôs hard to see this not ending in some market carnage. The current ‚Äúwinner-takes-most‚Äù mentality in the space means the bets are big and bold, but the market can‚Äôt support dozens of major independent AI labs or hundreds of application-layer startups. That‚Äôs the definition of a bubble environment, and when it pops, the only question is how bad it will be: a stern correction or a collapse.

Looking ahead

This was just a brief review of some major themes in 2025, but so much more happened. We didn‚Äôt even mention above how capable AI video synthesis models have become this year, with Google‚Äôs Veo 3 adding sound generation and Wan 2.2 through 2.5 providing open-weights AI video models that could easily be mistaken for real products of a camera.

If 2023 and 2024 were defined by AI prophecy‚Äîthat is, by sweeping claims about imminent superintelligence and civilizational rupture‚Äîthen 2025 was the year those claims met the stubborn realities of engineering, economics, and human behavior. The AI systems that dominated headlines this year were shown to be mere tools. Sometimes powerful, sometimes brittle, these tools were often misunderstood by the people deploying them, in part because of the prophecy surrounding them.

The collapse of the ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù mystique, the legal reckoning over training data, the psychological costs of anthropomorphized chatbots, and the ballooning infrastructure demands all point to the same conclusion: The age of institutions presenting AI as an oracle is ending. What‚Äôs replacing it is messier and less romantic but far more consequential‚Äîa phase where these systems are judged by what they actually do, who they harm, who they benefit, and what they cost to maintain.

None of this means progress has stopped. AI research will continue, and future models will improve in real and meaningful ways. But improvement is no longer synonymous with transcendence. Increasingly, success looks like reliability rather than spectacle, integration rather than disruption, and accountability rather than awe. In that sense, 2025 may be remembered not as the year AI changed everything but as the year it stopped pretending it already had. The prophet has been demoted. The product remains. What comes next will depend less on miracles and more on the people who choose how, where, and whether these tools are used at all.

Mid-year, momentum became visible. Community features came online. Ask-to-Earn stopped being a concept and started behaving like a system. Prompts turned into Gems. Gems pointed toward future value. The pieces began connecting, not because of marketing pressure, but because users kept showing up.

By September and December, the shift was clear. Multi-chain expansion. Zero Chat on BNB. Faster queries. Wallet analysis and DeFi actions in plain English. Infrastructure scaling without drama. Numbers climbing quietly: users, miners, prompts, subscriptions. Real usage, light marketing, organic monetization.

What stood out most wasn‚Äôt any single feature. It was how friction was handled. Badge resets answered with OG recognition. Engagement reinforced through trivia, game nights, seasonal campaigns, and transparent boosts. Systems adjusted to keep trust intact. Retention earned, not forced.

Narratively, 2025 was the year @ProjectZeroIO stopped experimenting and started preparing. Preparing for scale. For TGE. For a future where AI isn‚Äôt a layer on top of Web3, but something embedded deeply into how value, data, and ownership move together.

As the year closed, nothing felt rushed. The flywheel was already turning. Community-driven growth. Cross-chain expansion. Practical AI doing real work on-chain.

The bigger shift was narrative. Away from speculative churn. Toward rewarding participation, feedback-driven product cycles, and infrastructure that held up under 500k+ visits without blinking.

If 2) is right, then 1 is wrong.

Market returns are not a normal (Gaussian) distribution.

I was around for the Internet Bubble. There were so many companies with so much money chasing innovation. The number of companies that actually succeeded in the Internet bubble were extremely few and the number of investors who came out of it with profits were even fewer.

Why Bluwhale Focuses on Usable Outputs Instead of AI Hype Narratives

AI has become one of the loudest narratives in Web3. 

Every other project claims to be ‚ÄúAI-powered,‚Äù yet very few can clearly explain what actually improves for users or protocols once the buzzwords are stripped away. 

The result is an ecosystem full of promises, demos, and abstractions but limited real-world impact.

@bluwhaleai takes a different approach.
Rather than leading with hype, Bluwhale starts with a practical question: what decisions need to be made better in Web3 today? Most protocols don‚Äôt struggle because they lack data,they struggle because they lack clarity. 

They see transactions, but not behavior. 
They measure activity, but not intent. 
This gap is where Bluwhale applies AI not as a marketing layer, but as a utility layer.

The focus is on usable outputs.
Bluwhale‚Äôs AI models are designed to convert raw onchain signals into structured intelligence that teams can immediately act on. 

Instead of vague insights or flashy dashboards, the outputs are concrete: user segmentation based on behavior, engagement quality indicators, participation patterns, and contextual signals that inform product design, incentives, and growth strategies.

This matters because AI only becomes valuable when it changes outcomes.

A protocol doesn‚Äôt need to know that an AI model exists in the background. It needs to know which users are worth retaining, who is contributing long-term value, and how incentives should be allocated. 

Bluwhale‚Äôs outputs are built to answer those questions directly, reducing guesswork and replacing intuition with evidence.

Another key reason Bluwhale avoids hype is alignment with Web3‚Äôs core principles. 

Over-promising AI narratives often lead to opaque systems, centralized data extraction, and black-box decision-making. 

Bluwhale instead anchors its intelligence in verifiable onchain data, prioritizing transparency, permissioned access, and user sovereignty. 

The emphasis is not on showcasing complexity, but on delivering trustable, explainable insights.

By focusing on outputs, Bluwhale also lowers the barrier for adoption. Protocols don‚Äôt need to become AI experts or rebuild their stack. 

They can plug into an intelligence layer that delivers clear value from day one whether that‚Äôs smarter campaigns, better retention, or more efficient use of incentives.

In the long run, this philosophy positions Bluwhale as infrastructure, not spectacle. AI narratives come and go, but usable intelligence compounds. 

As Web3 products mature, teams will care less about who talks the loudest about AI and more about who quietly helps them make better decisions.

Bluwhale‚Äôs bet is simple: AI doesn‚Äôt need to be impressive it needs to be useful. 

By prioritizing usable outputs over hype, Bluwhale is building something that lasts.

The intentional refusal of @bluwhaleai to pursue fleeting narratives or superficial hype is what makes it unique.

Bluwhale is creating a world where AI operates as autonomous economic actors, operating on chain with embedded identity, durable context, and the capacity to carry out actual actions, in contrast to the majority of the ecosystem, which still views AI as little more than conversational wrappers.

Right now, the most powerful AI is controlled by a few giants (OpenAI, Google, Anthropic...). We use it for free (or pay), but the data, models, and compute are all locked away. Creators struggle to truly monetize their contributions, and users have no idea where the outputs come from or whether they‚Äôre trustworthy.

DeepNode aims to change that by building a truly decentralized AI network (DeAI + DePIN):

- Anyone can contribute: AI models, high-quality data, or idle global GPUs to run on-demand inference.
- Rewards are based on Proof-of-Work Relevance (PoWR) ‚Äì not raw hash power like BTC mining, but on real performance and usefulness of the model (verified on-chain).
- Full transparency: everything verifiable, no black box. IP belongs to creators, rewards fairly shared among node operators, validators, and contributors.

ü§ñ‚ù§Ô∏è AI in cardiovascular care: promise proven‚Ä¶ but only partially

This 2025 JACC Advances systematic review takes a hard, evidence-based look at what randomized controlled trials (RCTs) actually tell us about artificial intelligence in cardiology ‚Äî beyond hype and performance metrics  .

üîç What did the authors analyze?
Out of 930 screened studies, only 11 RCTs met inclusion criteria. Most were recent (2021‚Äì2024), multicenter, and focused on ECG, cardiac CT, or echocardiography. Importantly, the review assessed not only outcomes, but also risk of bias, conflicts of interest, and adherence to CONSORT-AI / SPIRIT-AI standards.

üìà Where AI really works
‚úÖ Early detection & screening: AI-ECG improved identification of low EF, atrial fibrillation, STEMI, and cardiomyopathies ‚Äî especially in large-scale, population settings.
‚è±Ô∏è Operational efficiency: consistent gains in workflow, reduced interpretation time, fewer unnecessary invasive angiographies, and better procedural planning with CT-based AI.
üìä Diagnostic accuracy often improved ‚Äî but this did not always translate into better outcomes.

‚ö†Ô∏è Where evidence is weak
Only 45.5% of trials showed improvement in clinical outcomes, and effects were often modest or limited to subgroups.
Hard endpoints (mortality, MACE) remain scarce.
63% of studies had moderate‚Äìhigh risk of bias, frequently related to funding or commercial interests.
Fewer than half complied with AI-specific reporting standards.

üß† Key insight
AI delivers its strongest value as a force multiplier: scaling screening, standardizing workflows, and optimizing resources ‚Äî not replacing clinical judgment.

üîÆ Bottom line
AI in cardiology is no longer science fiction, but evidence still lags behind adoption. To move from promise to practice, we need more independent, well-designed RCTs, focused on patient-relevant outcomes, not just speed or accuracy üöÄ

Inference Labs and Dagama Are Building the Trust Layer the Digital World Needs

As crypto and AI continue to evolve, one challenge keeps resurfacing trust. Not hype driven trust, but systems level trust that can scale across real world use cases. This is where Inference Labs and Dagama quietly separate themselves from the crowd.

Dagama focuses on fixing discovery at its root. The modern internet is full of reviews, locations, and recommendations, yet most of them are unreliable. Bots, paid shills, and fake engagement have eroded confidence. Dagama rebuilds discovery by anchoring data to real presence. Through verified check ins and proof of presence, contributions are tied to actual experiences. This turns exploration into a value generating activity where honest data is rewarded and manipulation becomes expensive.

Inference Labs addresses a parallel problem in intelligence. As AI systems increasingly influence decisions, opaque black box models are no longer acceptable. Inference Labs is building infrastructure for verifiable inference. Outputs are not just produced, they can be examined, validated, and trusted. This is critical for AI systems operating in finance, research, and other high impact environments where accountability matters.

Together, Dagama and Inference Labs represent a deeper shift happening across Web3. The move away from speculation and toward infrastructure. Away from attention based metrics and toward contribution based value. One grounds digital systems in physical reality. The other brings transparency and rigor to machine intelligence.

When real world signals meet verifiable intelligence, the result is a stronger foundation for decentralized applications. Not louder narratives, but lasting systems. As the space matures, projects like Inference Labs and Dagama show that trust is not a feature. It is the product.

Michael Burry, the investor famed for predicting the 2008 housing crash and portrayed in The Big Short, is once again betting against a perceived market bubble, this time in artificial intelligence.

Burry's hedge fund, Scion Asset Management, holds significant bearish put options on Nvidia and Palantir Technologies, two leading AI companies with combined valuations in the trillions. He views the ongoing AI investment frenzy as reminiscent of the dot-com bubble, warning that it may not be too early (or perhaps too late) to position against the sector's leading stocks.

The piece highlights Burry's ongoing criticisms, including concerns over circular financing in the AI ecosystem, aggressive depreciation assumptions for hardware that could inflate earnings, and potential overvaluation amid massive capital expenditures. DaGama rethinks mapping from the ground up. Its Real World Location (RWL) protocol on Arbitrum rewards users with $DGMA for validating physical places through repeated visits and trust scores that can‚Äôt be gamed. Why The AI Bubble Won't Bust

an smol essay by Lil' Triangle

As many of you are aware, AI is responsible for around 15% of society's ills, and that figure is growing. [1] The concept of 'Artificial Intelligence' has been a staple in the paper of modern society ever since the Jetsons or something. The term itself was never properly defined, because it's just an unoriginal garbo concept invented by the ancient Sumerians, who were like, "What if we could build a man out of parts?" This inspired the now-famous King, Hammurabi, to introduce the first Code of Laws to tell his subjects to not even attempt such a thing after the incident known as "Sagar's Foolishness". Near Nippur, Sagar son of Shar, attempted to create artificial intelligence, and in the process, accidentally blew up around 63% - 78% of Nippur, depending on which archeological source we're going with, but I'm biased towards Sir Nelson Carlson's higher estimate. Why? I don't need a reason. [2]

Forgetti the spaghetti on Ancient Wisdom, modern technology, computing, and software firms (who I will be referring to as 'Big Tech' henceforth. Perchance.) began to develop software programs that could take data inputs and "learn" from them. At first, this was fairly lame, but then, in 2011, Microsoft developed Watson, a computer that could play the TV game show, Jeopardy! This was an early example of a "Large Language Model" (which I will henceforth and forwarn that I shall refer to as an 'LLM'. Perchance.) algorithm. [3]

LLMs use very large data-sets to make predictions about which word should come ____. Art-based algorithms do something similar, but match keywords with images to 'predict' what the user wants. 90% of the time, this produces garbage outputs that the user then discards. 10% of the time, the output looks like what the user is envisioning, leading to the production what is known colloquially as "AI slop" or "AI brainrot". 

Now that we know what AI is, we must then ask: what has AI contributed to society? The answer, of course, is nothing. It is a huge joke. LLMs have allowed low-effort users to create 'slop mills', which make content for emotionally-neglected 5-year-olds with a smart tablet. By pure accident, the 5-year-olds will shift their focus from one piece of content to the next, often fueled by crippling ADHD.

Other groups that love AI content:

- Boomers
- Middle-age white men who think they have the best idea for a movie ever, and want AI to generate their dream movie, where a robot cowboy rescues a girl with big boobs from The Chinese. [4]
- Indian men
- Pakistani men
- Bangladeshi men
- Autistic Zoomers
- Gen Alpha Shitposters
- Politicians

That last category is particularly important, for reasons that will rapidly become clear.

There is currently a problem with 'AI': it requires a lot of resources to generate its slop. To meet user demand, AI software runs from these enormous data centers, which are filled with computer servers, all generating endless trash. The servers are much like your PC, unless you only have a smart phone. I think you should get a PC. Sike. You can't. Why? Because, much like your hypothetical PC, the servers in the data centers are using state-of-the-art RAM, memory storage, graphics cards, processors, and sometimes, really cool LEDs. This is causing the price of these parts to skyrocket, making it nearly impossible for you to afford a PC. 

When one runs a huge data-center, that huge data-center requires a massive input of electricity. With every Big Tech company building many data-centers to feed the growing need for slop, the question then becomes: do we have *enough* electricity? Currently yes, but if any company expects to allow millions of users to each create feature-length movies, then no. 

The amount of resources needed to sustain the current trajectory of AI growth are untenable and insufficient. 

Then, we have to ask: who's financing all this? Who is paying for the electricity? Who is building the data centers? Why is Big Tech operating at a loss to develop this technology? Why are there like 6,000 AI start-up firms?

Ostensibly, getting in the door early on an emerging technology could be the best gamble ever. Imagine if you purchased Bitcoin in 2011, and then became a billionaire within a few years. That's the thing investors are looking for; they want to find that next Bitcoin. They want to be a part of history. And so, they gamble. Personally, I bet all my chips on Nothing Ever Happens.

The promises AI companies make are nothing short of extravagant. All of your imagination can be manifested by computers at a whim. Any idea you have will be rendered into existence. Did you think of a movie? Well, it exists now. Do you want to write a song? It's written. A book? It's written. Even more wildly, Big Tech is claiming that AI is going to revolutionize medicine and cure cancer. I'm not even kidding. They're saying all of our cars can be driven by AI, and AI can babysit our kids, and AI can teach college courses, and AI can answer our phonecalls, and AI can write resumes, and AI can fuck our wife.

And make video games. All your video game ideas are going to be real. Trust me, bro.

The problem is that Big Tech consistently does not deliver such a product. It's still very janky, and limited, and creates unreliable, disgusting slop. You know, the stuff pigs will each out of a trough.

Unfortunately, there are just some hard limits on the advancement of technology. When computer chips are designed down to the nanometer, and the electrical power grid can only make so much lightning juice, the physical limit of what can currently be done becomes increasingly more difficult. Now, if we could get some thorium reactors going... but seriously... we're probably going to not get thorium reactors. Sorry, thorium enthusiasts.

What happens when AI hits its hard limit and billions of dollars go to waste? The entire economy collapses. Liberal Democracy is over. We're going back to despotism. I recommend investing in low-maintenance blade weapons, because all of the bullets are going to be used-up. You're also going to want to water-proof your bunker. I saw a video of a guy building a "bunker" by digging a pit and building a wood structure underground. That's not going to cut it. Rain is going to get in there. But also, mega-fauna will return. Large radioactive opossums will roam the streets of deserted cities in large packs.

Well, except for one thing.

The control of information is paramount to maintaining power in the world. Governments want to control perception without firing a single bullet, and that requires increasingly sophisticated means of propaganda. Imagine if China or Russia develop the hyper-real AI first. The United States government can't let that happen. Whoever gets that kind of power first is going to completely dominate the information battlefield. 

The government that can create any video of anything can do anything. Imagine the commander of the Chinese military receiving a phone call from the President of China. The President tells him to deploy the tanks to the streets and take control of Beijing. The Commander orders his troops to deploy at the behest of the President. Only the President never called him. And, oh no, the troops also received a fake call from the AI Commander telling them to detain the President.

It might not be THAT dramatic.

But it will be very powerful. During the Second World War, airplanes would fly over cities and drop millions of leaflets into the cities that just were pieces of paper with simple messages on them, telling the people to leave the cities. That was propaganda then. Imagine what we could do now.

I believe, for this reason, every major government is actively pursuing AI for intelligence and propaganda purposes. I have zero proof of this and no evidence, but I'm "probably right". [5] Therefore, AI cannot 'fail'. Governments can pump vast amounts of resources and money into these projects to keep them afloat until they can serve the needs of the state. Until then, people will keep wondering how the "AI bubble" has not burst yet. But you and I... we get it. 

Sources:

[2] oh, you think I need a source for this?
[3] The Bible
[4] I'm talking about YOU, Jason
[5] My Gut

China‚Äôs AI Progress Is Real ‚Äî The Hype Isn‚Äôt

https://t.co/1OEOq7z7ve

This is one of the best recent discussions on U.S.‚ÄìChina competition in AI and semiconductors: a fascinating, unusually well-informed exchange between @Gregory_C_Allen and @ChrisRMcGuire. Highly recommended for anyone serious about the subject.

Key takeaways that stood out to me:

China‚Äôs ‚ÄúEUV breakthrough‚Äù ‚Äî far less than the headlines suggest
What China has reportedly achieved is assembly, not indigenization:
‚Ä¢Assembled from globally sourced, ASML-adjacent components ‚Äî not a domestic supply chain
‚Ä¢A critical distinction between prototype, fab reliability, and mass production
This layered gap is the most underappreciated point. Even by China‚Äôs own internal estimates, 2028 is the target and mid 2030s more likely just to get ‚Äúworking chips‚Äù, not commercially competitive EUV.

Huawei: widening gap, not catching up
Huawei‚Äôs own roadmap versus NVIDIA‚Äôs implies the performance gap expands from ~5√ó today to ~17√ó within two years. More strikingly, Huawei‚Äôs next flagship AI chip (Ascend 950) is described as worse than its current generation ‚Äî and apparently lacking HBM. That‚Äôs a brutal signal. The surprise isn‚Äôt that China is trying; it‚Äôs the implied regression in a field where leaders almost never go backwards unless something structural is broken.

‚ÄúNo Nvidia smuggling‚Äù is fiction
They directly rejected Jensen Huang‚Äôs recent CSIS claim that ‚Äúservers weigh two tons, so smuggling is a myth.‚Äù Chris was blunt:
‚Ä¢DOJ has already busted smuggling rings (one case coincided with H200 licensing)
‚Ä¢BIS has testified to Congress that smuggling is real
Greg put it more diplomatically ‚Äî but not by much:
‚ÄúI would just be embarrassed professionally to be associated with that argument in any way.‚Äù

The real framework: make, buy, rent
Chris argued export controls only work if they block China from making, buying, and renting compute:
‚Ä¢Close equipment loopholes to stop domestic chipmaking
‚Ä¢Prevent large-scale chip purchases via third-country cutouts
‚Ä¢Most critically, end unrestricted remote access to cloud compute, which currently allows China to aggregate AI power abroad despite physical controls
His core point: compute access ‚Äî not chip ownership ‚Äî is the strategic resource, and virtual access must be regulated as seriously as physical possession.

China isn‚Äôt breaking through ‚Äî it‚Äôs working around constraints.
The gap isn‚Äôt closing; it‚Äôs widening, and only U.S. resolve and discipline will keep the edge in the most consequential technology competition.

Asked AI to summarize what to expect from the >50 page research paper 

. AI bottlenecks move from hype to constraints
AI adoption is accelerating at multiples of prior tech cycles, but 2026 is less about models and more about physical limits. The binding constraints are compute capacity, power, cooling, networking, and security rather than demand. Unlike the dot com era, this cycle is largely funded by cash flow and equity, not leverage, which materially lowers systemic risk. The takeaway is that AI becomes an infrastructure story, not a speculative software bubble, with earnings delivery replacing multiple expansion as the key driver. 
2026 outlook_ Looking for 5-10x‚Ä¶
2. Electricity becomes the real AI choke point
The limiting factor for AI scale is power availability, not chips. AI driven electricity demand could account for roughly half of total US power demand growth by 2026‚Äì27. Short term feasibility dominates ideology: solar and gas are the only scalable solutions on the required timeline, while nuclear remains a longer dated option. Grid equipment, storage, and ‚Äúpower to rack‚Äù infrastructure matter more than elegant long term energy narratives.
3. Rebuilding Ukraine is a balance sheet event
A likely end to open warfare in 2026 would unlock one of the largest reconstruction efforts in modern history. This is less about construction headlines and more about financial plumbing: credit creation, project finance, logistics, and EU compliant standards. Central and Eastern Europe act as the throughput zone for capital, materials, and labor, while Ukraine itself evolves toward a heavily armed, industrialized neutrality rather than demilitarization.
4. Military drones permanently change warfare economics
The Ukraine war has compressed decades of military evolution into a few years. Drones have structurally undermined the business case for tanks, fighter jets, and naval dominance due to extreme cost asymmetry. Even in a peace scenario, drone adoption continues as NATO spending rises and procurement rotates toward unmanned systems. 2026 is the year the market shifts from experimentation to scaled deployment.
5. US‚ÄìChina decoupling forces parallel supply chains
The US China trade relationship effectively freezes in 2026, accelerating forced CapEx into redundancy, reshoring, and security of supply. The most critical choke points are not finished goods but upstream inputs that cannot be substituted, particularly rare earths and nuclear related materials. Efficiency is knowingly sacrificed for resilience, creating state backed demand regardless of commodity prices.
6. Industrial robotics becomes survival CapEx
Tariffs and immigration restrictions collide with reshoring ambitions, creating an unavoidable labor shortfall. The response is not innovation spending but survival driven automation. Warehousing, logistics, manufacturing, healthcare, and services all see accelerated robot and AI adoption. This is early cycle, under crowded, and driven by necessity rather than optimism.
7. Alternative health shifts from fringe to policy backed
Mental health emerges as a structural pressure point in an economy facing automation, social dislocation, and declining job purpose. Regulatory momentum is building around non traditional therapeutics, with cannabis serving as precedent rather than the end goal. Psychedelic based treatments move toward clinical and political legitimacy, creating a potential regime shift in how mental health is treated and funded.
8. Crypto utility replaces crypto speculation
2026 is about crypto integration into the traditional financial system, not price narratives. Stablecoins become regulated financial infrastructure rather than speculative instruments, linking crypto directly to dollar funding markets, Treasury demand, and bank balance sheets. Adoption is driven by utility: payments, settlement, treasury management, and cross border flows. This is where crypto meets Wall Street, quietly but structurally.

I've been digging into AI tools lately, the ones that promise to turn our endless to do lists into something manageable. From what I've seen on their site, Veera strips away the barriers that keep AI out of reach for most people. You can "autobuild" these agents think digital sidekicks that handle research, juggle schedules, or sync up with your everyday apps like Notion or Google using simple templates. 

It's not about inventing the next ChatGPT; it's about making automation feel personal and practical.

Trump Says 'I Love AI' as Boom Bets Fuel Bubble Fears | Nicole Weatherholtz, Newsmax

The stock market was jittery in early November as investors again questioned whether Big Tech's massive artificial intelligence spending was outpacing reality.

The stock market was jittery in early November as investors again questioned whether Big Tech's massive artificial intelligence spending was outpacing reality. But inside the White House, the volatility barely seemed to matter.

Asked whether he feared an AI bubble could pop and damage the economy, President Donald Trump quickly dismissed the idea.

"No, I love AI," he said, according to The New York Times.

Over the past year, Trump and top aides have leaned fully into the technology, offering funding and regulatory support for AI's biggest corporate backers. The administration is betting that AI can drive one of the few major growth engines in an otherwise uncertain U.S. economy.

That confidence was on display Tuesday after the federal government reported that the economy grew at an annual rate of more than 4% last quarter. Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, told CNBC the numbers showed Trump's broader agenda was working, pointing to signs of a "boom" in AI.

Economists and even some Silicon Valley technologists remain more wary. Critics warn AI could bring significant job losses, at least temporarily, and worry the industry's rapid expansion could prove financially unsustainable.

Still, Trump ‚Äî who has long treated the stock market as a key measure of success ‚Äî has celebrated surging technology stocks, including Nvidia.

"Generative AI is a potential game changer for productivity and the economy," Glenn Hubbard, former chair of the Council of Economic Advisers under President George W. Bush, told the Times.

But he warned that the shift to AI could strain workers and communities as they adapt to the new technology.

"AI is happening rapidly, and we didn't help people cope with globalization and technological change very well over a 30- and 40-year period," Hubbard said. "We're probably not going to do it again."

Trump has pursued executive orders aimed at easing regulations for data centers, chips, and materials, guided in part by Silicon Valley investor David Sacks, who has compared AI skeptics to a "doomer cult."

The president has framed the AI race as a "fast-paced competition" with other superpowers and says it can create thousands of jobs ‚Äî even as the debate intensifies over whether growth will come without hiring.

Peter Navarro, Trump's top trade adviser, urged workers to consider employment in the trades.

These charts don‚Äôt show the AI bubble popping. They show the AI infrastructure financing bubble hitting physical constraints.

Oracle is down 33% because it pushed data center completion dates from 2027 to 2028 due to labor and materials shortages, while its bond yields blew out to 2009 levels and Blue Owl Capital walked away from a $10 billion financing deal over debt concerns. That‚Äôs a buildout execution problem, not an AI demand problem. Oracle‚Äôs remaining performance obligations hit $523 billion. They have more contracted AI business than they can physically deliver.

CoreWeave is down 39% because 62% of its revenue comes from Microsoft, which declined to exercise a $12 billion capacity option in March. Add a 1,262% debt-to-equity ratio and GPU rental rates that dropped from $5.50/hour to $1.55/hour as supply caught up to demand. That‚Äôs a customer concentration and commoditization problem, not AI failing.

Meanwhile, Nvidia is up 170% YTD. Microsoft‚Äôs AI run rate hit $13 billion, up 175% YoY. Google Cloud grew 31%. The actual AI layer is accelerating while the overleveraged infrastructure middlemen hit the wall that always comes when capital can be deployed faster than transformers and turbines can be manufactured.

This tells you exactly where the squeeze is: not in AI demand, but in the gap between financial ambition and physical reality. Oracle and CoreWeave bet they could build faster than physics allows and finance more than bond markets would tolerate.

The ‚Äúbubble pop‚Äù already happened, but only for the companies that confused raising debt with building data centers.

A lot of laptops and small PCs only work with SODIMM memory and JEDEC profiles, meaning no XMP or EXPO.

Crucial would always ensure their SODIMM kits had several JEDEC compliant profiles to fall back on, something a lot of other manufacturers like G.Skill and Corsair wouldn't always do.

People attending CES 2026 should be asking G.Skill, Corsair, TeamGroup, KLEVV, Kingston and any others, if they will fill this void.

‚ö†Ô∏è Unemployment is rising, yet a major divergence is unfolding ‚Äî and concerns about an AI bubble are growing.

Historically, rising unemployment has always been a very negative signal for financial markets.

However, after the pandemic, a significant divergence has emerged: unemployment started to rise again, while both the and moved higher ‚Äî with the S&P 500 being particularly surprising.

Let‚Äôs add more context:

1Ô∏è‚É£Currently, 59.6% of the U.S. population holds formal employment, well below the October 1999 peak of 64.6%. Has this decline been driven by the computing era and new forms of work?

2Ô∏è‚É£The Labor Market Stress Index has turned positive ‚Äî and that is a bad sign.
This is a powerful metric created by @Alphractal to identify meaningful shifts in labor-market conditions, with an optimal adjustment that helps filter out the current divergence between the economy and employment.
The Labor Market Stress Index measures job-market strain through the acceleration of unemployment. It tracks the gap between the current unemployment rate and its 12-month low, capturing early signs of trend reversals, and combines this acceleration with the absolute unemployment level, weighted 70% and 30%, respectively. Both components are normalized over a 5-year historical window. Elevated readings highlight not only high unemployment but also rapid increases ‚Äî conditions that have historically preceded recessions and signaled rising economic fragility.

3Ô∏è‚É£The KC Fed Labor Market Conditions Index is falling.
The bigger issue is if it continues to decline and turns negative. Historically, every time this happened, a prolonged bear market followed in the broader economy. This metric is especially valuable because it aggregates 24 different labor-market indicators into a single measure.

We can say that a bear market is almost inevitable ‚Äî but it takes time to materialize. What makes the current environment clearer is that these critical labor metrics continue to deteriorate despite the ongoing divergence: fewer formal jobs alongside an S&P 500 increasingly driven by artificial intelligence, a sector that generates relatively few formal jobs.

It is likely that by 2026, a major signal of weakness may emerge, and many analysts may characterize it as a potential AI bubble.

Overall, we need to monitor labor-market conditions on a monthly basis. Historically, they have been among the most reliable tools for anticipating an aggressive bear market well in advance.

I was asked to reflect on the big media stories of the part year. So here are five major happenings from 2025 that are worth further comment.

Big Thing 1: AI is reshaping us
There might be a debate about whether or not this is a bubble moment, but there is no doubt that AI products, and chatbots in particular, are now mainstream, entrenched, and reshaping how people get information. More time in chatbots means less time on traditional search, less time seeking out news sites, and more personalized information. But! It also increases the importance of person-to-person relationships, where each participant has real skin in the game. Even as we get more media from robots, we want more connection with humans. We want, and need, to share stories with each other. That‚Äôs an opportunity.

Big Thing 2: YouTube is king
Everyone within spitting distance of the New York Media Industrial Complex is obsessed with what‚Äôs happening at the TV stations, newspapers, and magazine empires, but they all are just mites in a bed that is built, made, and slept in by YouTube, which dominates news, commentary, and entertainment, and is well on the way to taking over not just our personal devices but also the living room. This was the year that Neal Mohan became the big, sexy boss that everyone wants to press flesh with. Next year could be the backlash‚Äîand if it happens, expect it to come from the conflict between the company‚Äôs ‚Äúcreator-first‚Äù messaging and the increasing abundance of AI-produced content (which is friendly to YouTube‚Äôs business model).

Big Thing 3: Paramount Skydance acquired The Free Press
When David Ellison‚Äôs company acquired Bari Weiss‚Äôs The Free Press, it was big news for obvious political and cultural reasons‚Äîand insider media gossip‚Äîbut to me the most significant story was that a new text-focused news and opinion publication had started from scratch, grown to significant revenue based on direct subscriptions, and then sold for a major sum after just three years. The media was supposed to be dying! Turns out that there is room for new entrants. There is room for reinvention.

Big Thing 4: Traditional media is washed out
There are a few traditional media institutions left standing‚Äîthe New York Times, Bloomberg, Wall Street Journal, the Financial Times, and a handful of others‚Äîbut the year 2025 confirmed that almost every other traditional media institution has completely lost influence. Worse: their businesses may not be recoverable. This reality is not the same thing as saying the media business is dead‚Äîit‚Äôs just not going to look like it has looked for the last 100 years. Even some of the biggest titans of that era won‚Äôt make the leap to the new era. This year has confirmed that we‚Äôre firmly in rebuilding territory now, even if the chaos of social media obfuscates the progress.

Big Thing 5: Direct relationships are the way forward
The traditional media system once thrived on direct relationships, with the big brands having built trust with their audiences over decades. That all fell to pieces in the social media era, when tech companies figured out how to best take advantage of the internet to monopolize attention and therefore ad dollars. The social media companies aren‚Äôt going to give up their riches any time soon, so the people who care about trustworthy media will have to build direct relationships with audiences all over again, except this time without relying on programmatic advertising and without letting the big platforms dictate what they can and can‚Äôt do with those audiences. In 2025, it has become clear that‚Äîbecause of platforms like Substack‚Äîpublishers can benefit from network effects that a platform brings without having to sacrifice the control of their audience relationships.

Part 1: Get Clear Before You Do Anything

before you try to convert a single conversation, you need to answer questions you've probably been avoiding

- write down why you want to exit. not the version that sounds good. what's actually true

- separate external noise (competitor raises, market panic, exhaustion) from internal signal

- is this your life's work or act one? neither answer is wrong but you need to know which one it is

- define what success looks like in real numbers. be specific

understand this: once you commit to selling, every decision optimizes for that outcome. you can't half-commit to an exit

the founders who struggle most are the ones running parallel tracks - trying to raise and trying to sell simultaneously. investors can smell it. acquirers can smell it. pick a lane

Part 2: Map Your Buyer Universe

you probably have 3-4 companies in your head that "might acquire us someday"

that's not enough. you need 20+

- list every company where your product could extend their roadmap

- research acquisition history. have they bought companies at your stage? your size?

- find founders they acquired. cold outreach if you have to. ask: how did it happen, who made the decision, what did the process look like

- identify overlapping customers. shared customers = easier integration story = higher willingness to pay

- understand their product roadmap. where's the gap you fill?

- note the financial structure of these companies, which companies have PE backing, which are venture funded, which are profitable, etc - try to figure out if they have cash to pay (it'll also help positioning it the right way with your investors and the board)

most founders skip this work and then wonder why they only got one lowball offer

Part 3: Reading Signals in Partnership Conversations

you're already talking to potential acquirers. you just might not know which ones yet

signals they're only interested in partnership:

- questions about APIs, SLAs, integration timelines
- focus stays on product mechanics
- conversation moves at normal business development pace
- only BD or product people in the room

signals something bigger might be brewing:

- questions about financials, runway, team size, your plans
- asking what you're thinking or where you're headed
- questions that go beyond partnership scope
- unusual urgency in scheduling follow-ups
- senior people showing up unexpectedly
- they start asking about your team's background and experience

if there's real acquisition interest, they won't wait for you to be obvious. they'll start asking the questions themselves

Part 4: The Slow Reveal

you cannot go from "let's discuss API integration" to "want to buy us?" in one conversation. that's how you kill deals before they start

stage 1 - relationship building (weeks 1-8)
- keep conversations product-focused
- build genuine rapport with people who matter
- understand their problems, roadmap gaps, strategic priorities
- gather intel on decision makers and internal politics
- do not mention acquisition. do not hint

stage 2 - strategic alignment (weeks 8-16)

- start discussing how your product fits their long-term roadmap
- share your perspective on where the market is going
- let them connect the dots between your capabilities and their gaps
- ask about their build vs buy philosophy (this is recon, not a pitch)
- still don't mention acquisition explicitly

stage 3 - soft signal (only when you sense reciprocal interest)

- mention you're "thinking about the next chapter" or "exploring what's next"
- gauge reaction carefully. do they lean in or change subject?
- clarifying questions = interest. moving on = not interested
- if they bite, you can be slightly more direct: "we've had some inbound interest and we're figuring out what makes sense"

stage 4 - explicit conversation (only after you have another horse in the race)

- once a different company is formally diligencing you, now you can be obvious with others
- this creates urgency without desperation
- "we're in conversations with a couple of strategic partners about potential acquisition and wanted to see if [company] might be interested"
- never be obvious before you have at least one real process running

Part 5: Timing the "Obvious" Moment

this is where most founders mess up. they either reveal too early (desperation) or too late (no leverage)

too early to be obvious:
- no one has expressed formal acquisition interest
- you haven't mapped the full buyer universe
- you don't have runway to walk away from a bad deal
- you're hoping someone will rescue you

right time to be obvious:
- one company has explicitly said they're diligencing you for acquisition
- you've signed mutual NDAs
- their team is actively reviewing your business
- you have enough runway to negotiate from strength

too late:
- after you've signed a term sheet with exclusivity
- now you can't talk to anyone else and you have no leverage

remember once you're obvious, word travels fast in your market. competitors will use it against you with shared prospects. customers may get nervous about signing annual contracts. there is no going back

Part 6: Separating Real Interest from Noise

you'll waste months chasing phantom interest if you can't tell the difference

it's real when:
- they send an NDA or ask you to send one
-they explicitly use the word "acquisition" not "partnership" or "strategic opportunity"
- they want financials, cap table, customer contracts
- conversations accelerate rapidly (weeks not months)
- decision makers are in the room or on the call
- corp dev gets involved (but is not only team) 
- they're asking about your team's retention and equity situation

it's noise when:
- conversations drag with no clear next steps
- they keep exploring but never commit to anything
- questions stay surface level
- only junior people are involved
- they're vague about timeline or process
- they want to "keep talking" indefinitely

slow conversations mean low interest. if they wanted you, they'd move fast. real deals happen in weeks. fake interest drags for months

Part 7: Running a Competitive Process

you have almost no leverage with one buyer. you have significant leverage with two or more
- never negotiate with just one party if you can avoid it
- use diligence with company A to create urgency with companies B and C
- verbal offers or term sheets are your key leverage points
- once you sign a term sheet you're usually in exclusivity - that's your last moment to create competition
- maintain warm relationships with backup buyers throughout the process
- warm relationships convert 10x faster than cold outreach when you need them

a sample phrase that creates urgency: "we're in active discussions with another party and expect to have a term sheet soon. wanted to give you a chance to participate in the process if there's interest"

Part 8: Protecting the Business During the Process

acquisitions fall through constantly. you cannot let your business die while chasing a deal
- assume anything you share could reach competitors
- be careful what you reveal before NDAs are signed
- competitors may weaponize "they're trying to sell" against you with shared customers
- keep your team focused on execution. tell them nothing until there's something real to tell
- don't let pipeline die. keep selling. keep shipping
- a business that's still growing is worth more than one that stalled during a sale process

Part 9: Understanding Valuation Reality

most founders have no idea how acquirers actually value companies at your stage

strategic acquisition math:
- buyer pays based on strategic value to them, not your revenue multiple
- what gap do you fill? what do they avoid building? what customers do you bring?
- lightning in a bottle is possible (someone pays $50M for a $600k ARR company) but it's not the median case
- your leverage: competing interest, strategic fit, team quality, technology moat, customer relationships

financial acquisition math:
- buyer pays based on cash flow potential
- at sub-$5M ARR, multiples are compressed (often 1-3x)
- they're buying a small business, not a strategic asset
- outcome often goes to founders OR investors, rarely both
- proceed only if you're okay with smaller numbers

the gap between these two is massive. a strategic buyer might pay $30M for something a financial buyer values at $1.5M. know which game you're playing

Part 10: The Process Timeline

knowing what normal looks like helps you spot when things are off

typical timeline:
- initial interest to term sheet: 4-12 weeks
- term sheet to close: 6-12 weeks
- fastest deals (strong buyer need, clean company): 2-3 weeks to term sheet
- slow deals (lukewarm interest): drag for months, often die

key milestones in order:
- first conversation that goes beyond partnership
- explicit statement of acquisition interest
- mutual NDA signed
- data room access shared
- management presentations / deep dives
- verbal offer
- written LOI or term sheet
- exclusivity period begins
- full legal and financial diligence
- definitive agreement signed
- close and wire

if you're stuck between steps for more than 2-3 weeks with no clear reason, something is wrong

Part 11: Who to Cultivate, Who to Deprioritize

your time is limited. spend it on people who can actually make things happen

prioritize:
- founders who sold to your target buyers (best intel you'll get)
- people with direct line to decision makers
- product leaders who own the roadmap you'd fit into
- corp dev if the company has an active M&A function
- executives who would sponsor the deal internally

deprioritize:
- people who can't influence decisions no matter how friendly they are
- BD folks with no strategic authority
- anyone who seems to be collecting intel rather than evaluating
- junior employees who take meetings but can't escalate

one warm intro to the right person beats twenty coffees with the wrong people

Part 12: Red Flags to Watch For

not everyone negotiating with you has your interests in mind
- buyer trying to extract IP through "partnership" before acquiring (or instead of acquiring)
- endless diligence with no movement toward term sheet
- verbal offers that never become written
- term sheets with unusual conditions, aggressive reps and warranties, or escrow that eats your proceeds
- pressure for exclusivity before they've given you real terms
- acqui-hire framing when they're really getting product + customers + team
- "we need more time" repeated more than once
- radio silence after you've shared sensitive information
trust your gut. if something feels off, it probably is

the meta point:

most founders in your situation know the options. the hard part isn't knowing what to do. it's deciding which path and committing fully

half-committed founders get half-committed outcomes. you can't simultaneously optimize for series A and strategic exit. pick the path that matches your internal motivation - not what vcs are telling you, not what other founders are doing, not what your investors want

then execute against that path with everything you have

the founders who get the best outcomes are the ones who answer the hard questions early, commit to a direction, and make every subsequent decision in service of that outcome

good luck
